title: Masterclass with Carlo Muscat
description: TONE, TIME, TACTIC - A personal approach to creative practiceThis workshop is based on developing a personal approach to practising improvised music. It focuses on the three main areas of sound, time, and technique, and is derived from Muscat's recent book Tone, Time, Tactic. He will share ideas he has used to shape his sound, learn tunes, and understand various aspects of the music. Muscat will also discuss methods for improving overall control and fluidity on wind instruments, which he developed from the teachings of the great saxophonist JD Allen. The methods also apply to other instruments since they are essential for ear training.Carlo MuscatRecognised as one of the most promising voices on the European jazz scene, Carlo Muscat's reputation as a saxophonist, composer, and bandleader has flourished through collaborations with numerous outstanding European musicians. His sixth album, Hymns, received critical acclaim, with a four-star rating from Downbeat Magazine and a spot on their Best Albums of 2023 list. This acknowledgement signalled his artistic development and emerging role in contemporary jazz. The eminent pianist Leo Genovese remarks, "Carlo's sound and compositions are outstanding, and the interplay between him and the ensemble shows a very deep communication with the tradition of improvising music."An inventive improviser overtly embracing a willingness to explore new musical territories, Muscat's discography now includes seven albums as a leader and numerous contributions as a sideman. From his 2014 debut release, The Sound Catalogues, each album has probed a different aspect of his sound and experimented with compositional and stylistic approaches, reflecting his dedication to an ongoing pursuit of his musical vision. World-class pianist Aaron Goldberg says "Carlo's fine taste is on display throughout−lyrical music with a bounce, refreshing in its conceptual simplicity."His seventh album, The Body Is Only Light, was recorded in Kyiv on Sunday 24th March 2024 and is set to be released in October 2024 on the American label ears&eyes Records.

title: Golden Ages: Hasidic Singers and Cantorial Revival in the Digital Era
description: A book talk and concert with Dr. Jeremiah Lockwood and Cantor Yoel KohnGolden Ages is an ethnographic study of young singers in the contemporary Brooklyn Hasidic community who base their aesthetic explorations of the culturally intimate space of prayer on the gramophone-era cantorial golden age. Jeremiah Lockwood proposes a view of their work as a nonconforming social practice that calls upon the sounds and structures of Jewish sacred musical heritage to disrupt the aesthetics and power hierarchies of their conservative community, defying institutional authority and pushing at normative boundaries of sacred and secular. Beyond its role as a desirable art form, golden age cantorial music offers aspiring Hasidic singers a form of Jewish cultural productivity in which artistic excellence, maverick outsider status and sacred authority are aligned.In this book event, Lockwood will discuss his new book and accompany one of the singers featured in the study, Yoel Kohn, in a concert of virtuosic and soulful cantorial performance in the early 20th century "golden age" cantorial style.

title: A Conversation on Creative Skills for Community Development: Liz Morgan, Theatre of the Oppressed
description: For our first conversation in the Creative Skills for Community Development series, Liz Morgan will share insights from her career in the arts and her current work with Theatre of the Oppressed NYC where she is the Director of Training and Pedagogy.  Liz Morgan is the Director of Training & Pedagogy at Theatre of the Oppressed NYC and a co-author of The Wildcard Workbook. In 2017, she initiated TO-NYC’s Rapid Response troupe, which specializes in experimental creative advocacy projects. Liz recently completed Columbia University’s Theatre of Change course in partnership with Broadway Advocacy Coalition where she developed Life, Liberty & the Pursuit of Happily Ever After, a Cinderella-inspired one-act aimed at inspiring immigration reform. Liz was a member of the NYC Narrative Power Network for Racial and Health Equity 2023 Cohort and her research with New York Presbyterian on Examining the Feasibility of Forum Theatre: An Innovative Approach to Dialogue Surrounding Bias and Barriers to Equitable Care was published in the Journal of Trauma Nursing. Before leaving to help form “The Fled,” a collective rooted in anti-racist values, Liz was also a resident writer at The Flea. Liz served on the A.R.T./NY Body Autonomy Leadership Council and TCG’s 2021 Rising Leaders of Color cohort. She holds both a B.A. and M.F.A. from Brown University.

title: Book Talk | Zainab’s Traffic: Moving Saints, Selves, and Others Across Borders
description: Join the Zolberg Institute for a discussion with Emrah Yıldız, author of Zainab's Traffic. What is the value—religious, political, economic, or altogether social—of getting on a bus in Tehran to embark on an eight-hundred-mile journey across two international borders to the Sayyida Zainab shrine outside Damascus? Under what material conditions can such values be established, reassessed, or transgressed, and by whom? Zainab’s Traffic provides answers to these questions alongside the socially embedded—and spatially generative—encounters of ritual, mobility, desire, genealogy, and patronage along the route. Whether it is through the study of the spatial politics of saint veneration in Islam, analysis of cross-border gold trade and sanctions, or examination of pilgrims women’s desire for Syrian lingerie accompanying their pleas with the saint in marital matters, the book and this talk develops the idea of visitation as a ritual of mobility across geography, history, and category. Iranian visitors’ experiences on the road to Sayyida Zainab—emerging out of a self-described “poverty of mobility”—demonstrate the utility of a more capacious anthropological understanding of ritual than our current predicaments allow for. Rather than thinking of ritual as a scripturally canonized manual for pious self-cultivation, Zainab’s Traffic approaches ziyarat as a traffic of pilgrims, goods, and ideas across Iran, Turkey, and Syria.

title: Philosophy Colloquium | Sabeen Ahmed, "Law and the Colonial Order of Things"
description: Abstract: This paper explores the limits of philosophy of law in addressing the prevailing political crises of our time--the dissolution of the so-called "rules based liberal order" and the fascist underpinnings of "Western" politics--by considering an alternative approach to legal analysis grounded in a Foucauldian conception of nomos. To show how modern law serves to reproduce global inequalities and hierarchies by institutionalizing and naturalizing colonial relations of force, it reconsiders modern law through the framework of power. In doing so, it posits a new reading of modern law as a technology for upholding what Aníbal Quijano has called "the Eurocentered capitalist colonial/modern world power," or what we can more simply understand as the colonial order of things. Bio: Sabeen Ahmed is Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Swarthmore College, where she works in the areas of social and political philosophy, philosophy of race, and anticolonial thought. Her teaching and scholarship take as their starting point the recognition that white supremacy is the defining political and existential problem of modernity, and that the discipline of philosophy has historically been implicated in this imperial reality. Her research and pedagogy are grounded in decolonial, antiracist, and anti-imperial commitments that bring global perspectives and historically marginalized voices to bear the major political (and thus philosophical) questions of our present.

title: Mannes Opera presents: Vinkensport, Or The Finch Opera and The Infinite Energy Of Ada Lovelace
description: Mannes Opera presents an Opera in Concert double bill featuring the works of Mannes faculty members and prolific composers David T. Little and Kamala Sankaram, directed by New School Drama alum Alison Pogolrec, offering an operatic lens into the strange world of human experience.Vinkensport, or The Finch Opera (2010/2018), composed by David T. Little on a libretto by Royce Vavrek, receives its New York City premiere with Mannes Opera. Vinkensport is a bitter-sweet comedy in one act, which explores obsession, desire, and the need to prevail, through the frame of an obscure Flemish folk sport, “finch-sitting.” Trained finches race to sing the most “susk-e-wiets” over the course of an hour. As they compete, the joys, sorrows, delusions and all-too-stark realities of their trainers are revealed. The Infinite Energy of Ada Lovelace (2019), composed by Kamala Sankaram with a libretto by Rob Handel, follows Ada, Countess of Lovelace and Lord Byron's daughter, who has been asked to help Charles Babbage with his work on the Difference Engine. She struggles between her work in mathematics and upholding her reputation as a wife, mother, and public figure. The revolutionary concepts that she put forth in her notes about the potential ability of the Engine to carry out an algorithm led Ada to be considered the world’s first computer programmer. "...an exuberant, rhythmically vibrant score by David T. Little with an infectious opening chorus."-The New York Times“[Kamala Sankaram] is one of the most exciting opera composers in the country.”-The Washington Post Vinkensport, or The Finch Opera by David T. Little, Libretto by Royce VavrekThe Infinite Energy of Ada Lovelace Music by Kamala Sankaram Libretto by Rob Handel Commissioned by Opera IthacaThe Infinite Energy of Ada Lovelace” is presented through special arrangement with UIA Talent Agency and Just a Theory Press.  MANNES OPERAUnder the leadership of Managing Artistic Director Emma Griffin, Mannes Opera is a dynamic training program for operatic artists, marked by a curiosity for new and a devotion to craft. The program utilizes opera as a medium for exploration, improvisation, and creation, providing students with extensive performance opportunities and practice.Recent notable productions include Grace McLean’s In the Green, Cavall’s La Calisto, Nico Muhly’s Dark Sisters, Die Zauberflöte, Rachel J. Peter’s Mermaid in the Jar, and Kate Soper’s Here Be Sirens.  With our commitment to developing and supporting new opera, we have workshopped Missy Mazzoli and Royce Vavrek’s The Listeners, Gregory Spears and Tracy K. Smith’s The Righteous (in collaboration with Santa Fe Opera), and David T. Little’s Agamemnon (in collaboration with Theatre for a New Audience).Our mission is to empower students to become versatile and self-assured professional artists, equipped with the skills and agency to navigate the ever-evolving landscape of the performing arts. Mannes Opera is committed to fostering artistic excellence and innovation, guided by the rich traditions of the past and a bold vision for the future. Mannes Opera’s 2024/25 Season opens with a jewelbox production of Don Giovanni created by Griffin and Mannes faculty member Cris Frisco, presented in a crisp 100 minutes, on October 18 and 19. The Opera in Concert double bill on November 8 and 9 features works by Mannes faculty members and prolific composers, David T. Little - Vinkensport, or the Finch Opera, New York premiere - and Kamala Sankaram The Infinite Energy of Ada Lovelace, directed by New School Drama alum Alison Pogolrec. On March 7 and 8, Mannes Opera presents Handel’s Alcina at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, directed by Sam Helfrich and conducted by Mannes alumnus Geoffrey MacDonald. On May 9, Mannes Opera gives a workshop presentation of Hildegard, a new opera by Sarah Kirkland Snider, in collaboration with Beth Morrison Productions. We look forward to seeing you!

title: New York City Graduate National Portfolio Day
description: What are National Portfolio Days?National Portfolio Days are annual events held in multiple locations across the United States, Canada and Europe. They are designed to provide a unique opportunity for you to meet individually with professional representatives of accredited art, design, and architecture colleges and universities. You'll be able to receive valuable feedback and guidance on your visual portfolio before you submit it as part of your admission application. Not all members schools attend each event. Visit nationalportfolioday.org for a complete list of schools attending each event, including November 10 in New York City.No admission decisions or scholarship awards will be offered to you at National Portfolio Days. Some college and university representatives may accept your portfolio as the visual portion of your application. Others have restrictions that prohibit them from making a definitive portfolio decision at the time of your review. All representatives will be happy to discuss their specific programs of study and provide answers to questions about the availability of scholarships and financial aid.You will not find National Portfolio Days to be an examination or competition; the events are about an exchange of information. The representatives want to learn about you, your work, and your post-secondary plans, all while informing you about their college or university and application requirements. These events may be the first time you have been in an environment with so many people in one place who all share a powerful commitment to art and design. Use this as an opportunity to be inspired, to gain advice as to how to improve or present your portfolio and to experience a small taste of what it is like to attend a professional art and design program.What is the National Portfolio Day Association?The National Portfolio Day Association (NPDA) was created in 1978 solely for the organization and planning of National Portfolio Days. The Association consists of representatives that hold regional accreditation and accreditation from the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD), or Substantial Equivalency status. NPDA is the only organization of its kind and the membership represents the highest standard of visual arts education available in the world.What should I bring to a National Portfolio Day?A portfolio of visual artwork that includes your best and most recent work, but it can also include works in progress, sketchbooks and tear sheets. Don’t hesitate to explain how you develop your ideas and where you want to go with them. Often, sharing the process of arriving at the completed work is as valuable as simply presenting finished products. You will hear many different opinions about your work that will be reflective of the admission requirements of each school. Therefore, we urge you to discuss your work with as many colleges/universities as possible and to bring no more than 15 works. Your portfolio can be presented as original work or on screen, but make note wifi may not be available at all locations. Students who are not prepared to show a portfolio may attend to gather information from college/university representatives.All National Portfolio Day events are free and open to the public.

title: I HOPE THIS HELPS: In Pursuit of a Restorative Poetics
description: Exploring work from her solo multimedia exhibitions featuring multi-sensory poetic installations and her forthcoming new book, I HOPE THIS HELPS (Nightboat Books, Spring 2025), Samiya Bashir will read, perform, and screen selections of the work and engage in dialogue about the pursuit of a restorative poetics which, through both process and product, might open up new paths from isolation toward revivification and healing. Drawing on her vast background as an organizer, award-winning artist and poet, scholar and teacher and a student of June Jordan’s, Bashir will bring together shared experiences of upheaval, displacement, and the relentless pursuit of hope amidst uncertainty.About the SpeakerSamiya Bashir is a poet, writer, librettist, performer, and multi-media poet whose solo and collaborative work has been widely published, performed, installed, printed, screened, experienced, awarded and Oxford comma’d from Berlin to Düsseldorf, Amsterdam to Accra, Florence to Rome, and across the United States. Sometimes she makes poems of dirt. Sometimes zeros and ones. Sometimes light. Bashir is the author of three poetry collections, most recently Field Theories, winner of the Oregon Book Award. Other honors include the Rome Prize in Literature, the Pushcart Prize, New York Council for the Arts and Oregon’s Regional Arts & Culture Council fellowships, among numerous other awards, grants, and residencies. In addition to her books, Bashir has served as editor to national magazines and anthologies of literature and artwork. In 2002 she was co-founder of Fire & Ink, an advocacy organization and writer’s festival for LGBT writers of African descent with whom she worked through 2015. A sought-after editor, Bashir most recently served as Associate Professor at Reed College, and executive director of Lambda Literary. She currently serves as the June Jordan Visiting Scholar at Columbia University.

title: Multidisciplinary and Multiperspective Engagement with Early Ceramics
description:
RSVP Required

Speaker: Anke Hein

The Intersection of Past, Present, and Future in Research on Painted Pottery

This lecture will take place online. Registration is required; click through for the registration link. Zoom information will be provided via confirmation email to registered participants. As they are ubiquitous in the material record, ceramics have long been a major concern of archaeological research. To gain further insight into processes of ceramic production and related socio-cultural issues, in many parts of the world has become common to refer to ethnographic data and conduct ethnoarchaeological studies.

title: Exhibition Lecture
description:
RSVP Required

Speaker: Abigail Balbale

"The Sight that I Offer is the Fairest of Sights": Ivory, Concubines, and Transcultural Exchange in Umayyad Cordoba

This lecture will take place in person at ISAW. Registration is required; click through for the registration link. This lecture is given in conjunction with ISAW's exhibition Madinat al-Zahra: The Radiant Capital of Islamic Spain. Of the many beautiful objects associated with Madinat al-Zahra and the Cordoban Umayyad caliphate, perhaps none are as celebrated as a series of ivory pyxides and caskets produced for members of the royal family.
department: Institute for the Study of the Ancient World
tag_note: Assigned academic topic as History, Language, Archaeology and Other for transcultural. Closest tags can be Ivory, Umayyad and Cordoba. Since this is an exhibition lecture, therefore assigned tags: Exhibition, Lecture and Transcultural. Main category is Academic as this event has academic topic discussed and it seems to be part of exhibition.

title: Left Adrift: A Conversation with Timothy Shenk
location: Book Culture, 536 West 112th Street, New York, NY 10025
description:
<p>Join <a href="https://globalreports.columbia.edu/" target="_blank"><strong>Columbia Global Reports</strong></a> to celebrate the publication of <em>Left Adrift</em> by alumnus <strong>Timothy Shenk </strong>(&rsquo;07CC &rsquo;16GSAS) at <strong>Book Culture</strong> (536 West 112th Street). Tim will be joined in coversation by&nbsp;<strong>Andrew Delbanco,&nbsp;</strong>Alexander Hamilton Professor of American Studies at Columbia University and president of the Teagle Foundation.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p>Can Kamala Harris energize the Democratic Party to once again become the party of the working class? In&nbsp;<em>Left Adrift</em>, historian Timothy Shenk provides a new perspective on the transformation of the left over the last 50 years, offering compelling insight into the recent history of the Democratic Party, and, on the eve of a major US election, a look towards its future.</p>

title: Composer Portraits: Miguel Zenón
location: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Acclaimed composer and saxophonist Miguel Zen&oacute;n has earned a prestigious array of accolades, including fellowships from both the MacArthur and Guggenheim Foundations, a Grammy Award, and a Doris Duke Award. His influence in the world of music is wide-ranging, characterized by a compositional style that masterfully blends jazz with his many musical influences. For this Portrait an all-star large ensemble performs the New York premiere of&nbsp;<em>Golden City,</em>&nbsp;an important evening-length multimedia work created in tribute to the immigrant communities of San Francisco.</p>

title: Infections in Hospitalized Patients 2024
Sonic Shatterzones: Hearing the Intertwined Spaces
location: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027	Marshall D. Shulman Seminar Room, 1219
description:
<p>Please join the Harriman Institute for a Director&#39;s Seminar with <strong>Alexandra Birch</strong>. Moderated by <a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/valentina-izmirlieva/"><strong>Valentina Izmirlieva</strong></a>.</p>
<p>The history of the Soviet Union can be defined by periods of atrocity, genocide, and warfare. The Soviet Gulag, the Holocaust, and the civilian and military engagement in World War Two produced unfathomable mass death in sites across the entire USSR for a half-century. Music and sound provide an instant, humanizing, and immersive understanding of these atrocities. In four case studies, Birch will provide examples of how we can hear the Holocaust, the Gulag, Terror, and exile. She will discuss Weinberg&rsquo;s sonic fragment&rsquo;s taken to Tashkent and covertly buried in his violin sonata during a peak of Soviet antisemitism in 1948, sonically describe the Gulag between field recordings of Karlag and the recovered music of Nosyrev and Zaderatsky, look at the overlap between Nazi and Soviet occupation of indigenous space and present Saami recordings as reassertion against epistemicide, and discuss how we can hear the Holocaust in the Soviet context both with recovered music (Tyrmand, Leyvand) and through sound. Finally, where do we go from here? In the wake of renewed Russian expansion and aggression, how do composers like Khanon, Gubaidulina, and Stolyar provide a sonic and intellectual intervention against terror? Rather than an intellectualized view of political violence, music and sound connect us to impossible catastrophe and create an emotional and evocative response to historical events.</p>
tag_note: The event is a seminar with a focus on the history of the Soviet Union and the use of music and sound to provide an immersive understanding of atrocities. The main category is Academic and the event type is Seminar. The academic topics are History and Other, as the event covers a broad range of historical topics. The tags are Lecture, Music, and History, as they capture key aspects of the event.

title: Essentials of Evidence-Based Assessment of OCD
description: <p>During this course, participants will learn the fundamental components of assessing obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Participants will learn to conduct a hands-on evidence-based evaluation and develop confidence in administering the Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS), the gold standard instrument in the evaluation of OCD. Participants will learn to engage in a thoughtful differential diagnosis process that will help inform and guide case formulation and treatment planning.</p>

title: Dive Into Budgeting
description:
<p>Balancing a personal or household budget can be an enormous task, and many of us do mental gymnastics in an attempt to keep it all straight in our heads. Even with a budget that&#39;s balanced on paper, it might feel like everyday life occurrences are constantly knocking you off track, making it impossible to reach long term goals. In this webinar a TrustPlus financial coach will walk through some budgeting fundamentals to help reframe how you think about budgeting and share techniques for developing a budget that better reflects your day-to-day experiences.</p>
<p>Presenter: A&nbsp;TrustPlus financial coach with Neighborhood Trust Financial Partners</p>
tag_note: The event is categorized as Other because it is primarily a financial workshop. The tags are related to budgeting and personal finance.

title: Weight Management Basics
description:
<p>Discover realistic strategies and lifestyle changes to help you begin your weight-management journey or stay on track with personal goals to optimize your health.&nbsp; During this session you will learn evidenced-based nutrition and weight management practices and how to best utilize them in a sustainable way.&nbsp; We will also explore tips around healthy eating and maintenance around the holiday season!</p>
<p><strong>Instructor:&nbsp;</strong>J<strong>amie&nbsp;Leskowitz</strong>&nbsp;is a Registered Dietitian and Certified Diabetes Educator practicing at the <a href="https://www.columbiaendocrinology.com/wcc" target="_blank"><strong>CUIMC Metabolic and Weight Control Center</strong></a>. She is passionate about helping others manage weight and improve health-related conditions by finding a sustainable and balanced eating lifestyle. She specializes in weight management and related conditions, including pre-diabetes, type 2 diabetes, heart disease, polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and weight regain after weight loss surgery</p>

title: Salzberg Chemistry Seminar: Prof. George John, “Molecules To Materials – Biomass as A Platform for Molecular Design
description:
Salzberg Chemistry Seminar: Prof. George John, “Molecules To Materials – Biomass as A Platform for Molecular Design
Salzberg Chemistry Seminar: Prof. George John of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, City College of New York will discuss "Molecules To Materials - Biomass as A Platform for Molecular Design."
Abstract: Developing functional materials from renewable resources would be fascinating yet demanding practice, which will have a direct impact on industrial applications, and economically viable choices. This talk discusses an emerging model of generating new chemicals, intermediates, soft matter and energy storage components from biomass. Our continued efforts over two decades in this area have led us to develop new materials from molecules derived from industrial by-products and co-products. The family of new materials generated include molecular gels, solid bilayers, scintillating gels, battery components, liquid crystals, and polymers. Intriguingly, following the principles of green and supramolecular chemistry, we have developed building blocks-to-assembled materials viz environmentally benign antibacterial paints, oil spill recovery materials, energy storage devices, vegetable oil structuring agents and cancer detecting gels. These results will lead to efficient molecular design of supramolecular architectures, soft matter, and next generation multifunctional interfacial chemicals from underutilized plant/crop-based renewable feedstock.

title: Gaymers Against Violence: Monthly Workshop Series
description:
Gaymers Against Violence: Monthly Workshop Series





Join The CCNY LGBTQ+ Student Center, NYC Gaymers, Crime Victims Treatment Center, and the NYC Anti-Violence Project to play video games and more while learning anti-violence prevention best practices! This is a monthly interactive and community-led gaming space, where students will learn how to navigate, address, and prevent interpersonal violence within their relationships and communities. Open to all CCNY and CUNY!
Reminder to RSVP for the event date you are attending!
Location: The CCNY LGBTQ+ Student Center (NAC 1/101B)
Time: 12PM - 2PM
Dates and Topics:

Tuesday, Sept. 24: LGBTQ+ 101 & Types of Attraction
Tuesday, Oct. 29: Navigating Intimate Partner Violence in the LGBTQ+ Community
Tuesday, Nov. 26: Creating Your Community of Care
Tuesday, Dec. 10: Upstander/Bystander Intervention
*TENTATIVE* Tuesday, Jan. 28: “LGBTQ+ Mental Health
*TENTATIVE* Tuesday, Feb. 25: Sex Jeopardy & Healthy Relationships
*TENTATIVE* Tuesday, Mar. 25: Healthy Masculinity & Intersectionality
*TENTATIVE* Tuesday, Apr. 29: Title IX/Supporting Sexual Violence Survivors in LGBTQ+ Communities
*TENTATIVE* Tuesday, May 13: Safer Partying During Pride

Games Include:

Super Smash Bros.
Mario Kart
Jackbox TV Games
Uno
Dominoes
Playing Cards
A Variety of Tabletop Games

About the CCNY LGBTQ+ Student Center
The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer and Questioning Student Center (est. Fall 2021) is a collaborative resource dedicated to celebrating, empowering, and supporting LGBTQIA+ students, staff, and faculty at CCNY. We are committed to leading with a social justice lens, offering and connecting LGBTQ+ communities at CCNY with accessible support services, relevant programming, engaging events, paid internship/job opportunities, and general guidance navigating college, home life, and futures outside of higher education for those who identify as LGBTQ+ or questioning. The LGBTQ+ Student Center is also dedicated to increasing awareness about LGBTQ+ issues, gender, and sexuality at City College. The LGBTQ+ Student Center is a safe space for all LGBTQIA+ students and allies to meet and build community. You all are welcome here!
About NYC Gaymers
NYC Gaymers (est. 2012 ) began as a member-led community of LGBTQIA+ gamers, moving to uplift the voices of marginalized gamers, and sustain a space that shares a diversity and passion that is reflective of both New York City and Gaming culture. NYC Gaymers Inc. empowers gamers across the intersections of orientation, identity, expression, race, and ability, in order to uplift and center our most marginalized community members through education, advocacy, and the creation of safer spaces.
About Crime Victims Treatment Center
CVTC (est. 1977) is a not-for-profit organization committed to helping people heal from violent crime. We respect that healing comes in many forms and recognize the importance of a holistic approach. CVTC provides a wide range of therapeutic services free of charge to anyone impacted by violence. We are dedicated to advocacy on behalf of survivors, collaboration with partners across a multitude of disciplines, and training for those who work with survivors. We are committed to changing cultural norms around violence and promoting social justice through progressive legislation and community mobilization.
About The Anti-Violence Project
AVP (est. 1980) empowers lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, and HIV-affected communities and allies to end all forms of violence through organizing and education, and supports survivors through counseling and advocacy. AVP envisions a world in which all lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, and HIV-affected people are safe, respected, and live free from violence.
This event is made possible due to generous funding from the NYC Council's LGBTQIA Caucus, the Office of the Mayor, and supported by the CUNY LGBTQIA+ Consortium through the LaGuardia and Wagner Archives.
This event will be archived at the LaGuardia and Wagner Archives.
Co-sponsors: NYC Gaymers, NYC Anti-Violence Project, NYC Crime Victims Treatment Center, CCNY Gaming Pathways, The LGBTQ+ Student Center at CCNY, The LGBTQ+ Open Alliance Club, the CUNY LGBTQI+ Council, CCNY Office of Diversity and Compliance, The CUNY Office of Diversity and Inclusion Initiatives,The CCNY Department of Student Life and Leadership Development, CCNY Gender Resources, and the City College Division of Student Affairs.
The City College of New York and the CCNY LGBTQ+ Student Center are a proud members of the CUNY LGBTQIA+ Consortium.
QUESTIONS? email us at lgbtq@ccny.cuny.edu
SPACE LIMITED

title: Stuart Z. Katz Professor in the Humanities & Arts: Installation & Lecture
description:
Stuart Z. Katz Professor in the Humanities & Arts: Installation & LectureStuart Z. Katz Professor in the Humanities & the Arts

A special celebration for Professor Boukary Sawadogo as The 2024-2025 Stuart Z. Katz Professor in Humanities and the Arts. Prof. Sawadogo's lecture: Of Here and Afar: The World in Me. Our identities are not static or singular, but instead are cobbled together out of many influences, strands, and experiences. Answering the question of how one becomes oneself often requires that we reencounter the community that saw us come of age, navigate transnational influences, and engage with the world in terms of one’s place and trajectory in it.
The Stuart Z. Katz Professorship in the Humanities & the Arts at The City College of New York was established in 2017 by a generous gift from Mr. Stuart Z. Katz, a 1964 Phi Beta Kappa graduate of CCNY. The endowment supports one outstanding professorial faculty member in the Division of Humanities & the Arts for an academic year, providing the professor up to two months of summer salary plus $10,000 to support research and creative activity.
Mr. Katz, a retired attorney, established the gift for the importance of the study of humanities and the arts for a thorough education and life.

title: Parsons Fine Arts: Visiting Artist Lecture Series
description: We are pleased to announce the Fall 2024 lineup for the Visiting Artist Lecture Series.These events are free and open to the public.Join us most Wednesdays at 7pm through out the fall for dynamic talks by inspiring contemporary artists.

title: Visiting Artist: Anna Martine Whitehead
description: Anna Martine Whitehead does performance from the homelands of the Council of the Three Fires: The Odawa, Ojibwe and Potawatomi Nations; as well as the Miami, Ho-Chunk, Sauk and Meskwaki; the Kiikaapoi, Peoria, and the Očeti Šakówiŋ (Sioux) Nations. Their solo and collaborative work has been presented by the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art; REDCAT; Portland Institute for Contemporary Art; Chicago Symphony Orchestra; Museum of Modern Art; San José Museum of Art; Links Hall; and Yerba Buena Center for the Arts. She has developed her craft working closely with Takahiro Yamamoto, Onye Ozuzu, Jefferson Pinder, taisha paggett, Every house has a door, Keith Hennessy, BodyCartography Project, Julien Prévieux, and the Prison + Neighborhood Art Project, among others. She has been recognized with awards and fellowships from the New England Foundation for the Arts, National Performance Network, Graham Foundation, Vera List Center for Art and Politics, MAP Fund, Dance/USA, PICA Creative Exchange Lab, University of Chicago Arts + Public Life, 3Arts, Chicago Dancemakers Forum, Foundation for Contemporary Arts, Headlands Center for the Arts, and Rauschenberg Foundation. Martine has written about blackness, queerness, and bodies in action for Art21 Magazine, C Magazine, frieze, Art Practical; and contributed chapters to a range of publications including Queer Dance: Meanings and Makings (Oxford, 2017), Organize Your Own: The Politics and Poetics of Self-Determination Movements (Sobsercove, 2016), and Platforms: Ten Years of Chances Dances (2016). Martine is the author of TREASURE | My Black Rupture (Thread Makes Blanket, 2016).
tag_note: I chose Performance Art, Dance, and Artist Talk as tags since Anna Martine Whitehead is a performance artist and the event involves a talk. The main category is Performance since the event is centered around the artist's performance work. I chose Other under academic topics since Parsons School of Design is the hosting department.

title: Pianographique-music of Glass, Reich, Anderson, Rani
description: PianographiqueFeaturing Maki Namekawa & Dennis Russell Davies with visuals by Cori O’LanU.S. PREMIERE: Elergy for the Present (2020) - Philip Glass The Namekawa-Davies Duo present Pianographique, an evening of music featuring works by Philip Glass, Laurie Anderson, Steve Reich and Hania Rani, with real-time visualizations by Cori O’Lan.The concert features Steve Reich’s iconic Piano Phase (1967), two pieces by Laurie Anderson including Bob and Bill, and a second half comprised of works by Philip Glass, including the U.S. premiere of Elergy for the Present (2020), music from The Truman Show, and Four Movements for Two Pianos, which Glass composed for the Namekawa-Davies Duo.  We are pleased to announce that Hania Rani's Hawaii-Oslo and Glass are new additions to this program.Free with registration / Space is limited.Presented by Mannes School of Music at The New School College of Performing Arts
location: Auditorium at 12th Street at The New School
tags: auditorium at 12th street at the new school

title: The History of French Lace: Tradition & Innovation of an Haute Couture Craft
description: François Damide of Solstiss Lace will present on the history of French lace-making, from bobbin to leavers lace, to further innovations such as vinylized, flocked, or biodegradable nylon lace.François will also touch on the role of lace today, elevated as an essential part of haute couture craft (think Chanel's Métiers d'arts shows), featured in period shows like The Gilded Age or worn by music icons Beyoncé and Madonna.
tag_note: Assigned 'Other' as an academic topic since French lace-making is not explicitly mentioned in the list, although it is related to haute couture and design.

title: ONLINE | A Conversation with Oscar Nominee Laura Checkoway
description: “Alt Shift Life” is a Tribeca Studios and Lief production in partnership with ServiceNow, exploring the impact of AI on the modern job market. This film follows three inspiring young adults who have faced unique challenges and forged their paths in tech: Sai from India, Scott from rural Tennessee, and DeVonn from the Bronx. Through their stories, director Laura Checkoway skillfully depicts their struggles and aspirations.Laura Checkoway is an Oscar and Emmy nominated filmmaker known for intimate character-driven stories. Join Checkoway, film participant Scott, plus an executive producer from ServiceNow, as they discuss their creative vision for the project and how it aligns with ServiceNow’s mission to educate potential employees. Highlighting ServiceNow’s RiseUp program, the film aims to connect diverse talents with career opportunities in the tech industry.
tag_note: The event is a discussion on a film exploring the impact of AI on the job market, hence the main category is Academic and the event type is Panel Discussion. Tags are assigned based on the film's topic, and academic topics are chosen as the film relates to computer science and AI.

title: Visiting Artist: Hannah Levy
description: Hannah Levy was born in 1991 in New York City, New York, where she currently lives and works. The artist received a BFA from Cornell University in 2013 and a Meisterschüler title from Städelschule in Frankfurt am Main in 2015. Levy’s sculptures are uncannily familiar, transforming ubiquitous elements of interior design into unnamable objects that appear to merge the organic and the industrial. Through her practice, the artist calls attention to the relationship between our bodies and the built environment, considering how we are impacted by the design choices around us.

title: Joe's Blackbook 2025 Design Scholarship Info Session
description: This info session and scholarship are limited to Y3 Fashion Design students only. Sean Kwon and Dash Brahmann from Joe's Blackbook will be on campus to kick off their 2025 Design Scholarship competition. They will talk about JBB's role in the fashion industry as well as all of the information you need to know to apply for the $10,000 design scholarship.We encourage you to stay after the info session for AI-Powered Creativity: Transforming Fashion with Generative Tools from 4-6pm. The New School's Maya Georgieva will live demo techniques for using generative image-based AI software like playground.ai and Adobe Firefly for fashion design. You'll come away with tips that will help you iterate and explore ideas faster, as well as create work that expresses your own specific style—responsibly. This talk will also explore questions around ethical considerations, sustainability, and implications of AI for design and the world.
tag_note: The event is an info session limited to Y3 Fashion Design students, with a focus on the 2025 Design Scholarship and AI-Powered Creativity

title: AI-powered Creativity: Transforming Fashion with Generative Tools
description: Curious about how generative AI can enhance the fashion design process and unlock new creative possibilities? Join Maya Georgieva (Senior Director of the Innovation Center and XR, AI, and Quantum Labs) for an insightful exploration of how generative AI is transforming the fashion industry. Discover practical ways to integrate AI into your design workflow, enhancing creativity and efficiency. Through live demonstrations of cutting-edge tools like Adobe Firefly, playground, Midjourney, and others, you'll learn how to develop and iterate ideas faster while staying true to your unique style.Learn how leading fashion houses and design studios are already implementing these technologies, and discuss opportunities for your creative practice. This talk will also discuss ethical considerations, sustainability, questions around ethical attribution in creative work, as well as the broader implications of AI on design and society.Whether you're excited or skeptical about AI's role in fashion, this session will provide valuable insights and practical techniques, empowering you to responsibly leverage generative AI in your design process.

title: GIDEST Seminar with Beatriz Colomina
description: Please join us for a seminar with Beatriz Colomina, Howard Crosby Butler Professor of the History of Architecture at Princeton University, who will present work-in-progress devoted to exploring alternative architectural and political paradigms inspired by the relationship between built environments, bacteria, and the microbiome.  Beatriz Colomina has written and curated extensively on questions of architecture, art, technology, sexuality, and media. Her scholarly books include Radical Pedagogies (2022), X-Ray Architecture (2019), Are We Human? Notes on an Archeology of Design (2016), The Century of the Bed (2015), Das Andere/The Other: A Journal for the Introduction of Western Culture into Austria (2016), Manifesto Architecture: The Ghost of Mies (2014), Clip/Stamp/Fold: The Radical Architecture of Little Magazines 196X-197X (2010), Domesticity at War (2007), Privacy and Publicity: Modern Architecture as Mass Media (1994), and Sexuality and Space (1992).  She has lectured extensively at universities, museums, biennales, festivals, and foundations on every continent—including the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Architectural Institute of Japan, the Guggenheim in New York, the Center for Contemporary Art and Architecture in Stockholm, the Centre Pompidou in Paris, the DIA Art Foundation in New York, Tate Britain in London, among many others. She has also curated a series of international exhibitions, based on archival and oral history research, as interfaces to communicate research to a wider audience with physical installations, digital platforms and new forms of publication.  Colomina has been the recipient of numerous awards and fellowships, including the Samuel H. Kress Senior Fellowship at the CASVA (Center for Advanced Studies in the Visual Arts), SOM Foundation, Le Corbusier Foundation, Graham Foundation, the CCA (Canadian Centre for Architecture), The American Academy in Berlin, the Getty Center in Los Angeles, the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, and the Wissenschaftkolleg in Berlin. She is on the advisory board of multiple institutions, including The Norman Foster Foundation in Madrid, The Istanbul Design Biennial, The Institute for Innovation and Creative Strategies in Architecture in Lyon, ARCH+ in Berlin, The Oslo Center for Critical Architectural Studies (OCCAS), Beyond Media in Florence, and The Storefront for Art and Architecture in New York. In 2020, she was awarded the Ada Louise Huxtable Prize for her contributions to the field of architecture, and, in 2022 she was inducted into the Royal Academy of Doctors of Spain. This seminar is a discussion of a pre-circulated work. It can be found on the GIDEST site for attendees to read in advance. This event is part of the bi-weekly GIDEST Seminars presented by the Graduate Institute for Design, Ethnography & Social Thought.
location: The New School University Center, GIDEST Lab, Room 411
department: The New School For Social Research

title: Islam in the African Renaissance: The Secular-Religious Afterlife of Shaykh Musa Kamara
description: The African Studies Initiative (ASI) presents: Islam in the African Renaissance: The Secular-Religious Afterlife of Shaykh Musa KamaraWendell Marsh, Assistant Professor of Africana Studies at Rutgers University-Newark presents Islam in the African Renaissance. "The broader project narrates the efforts of Senegalese Muslim scholar Shaykh Musa Kamara (1864-1945) to publish a monumental history of Muslim West Africa in a bilingual Arabic-French edition. In so doing, I describe the evolving relationship between forms of knowledge and forms of power before, during, and after the colonial episode, in which Arabic was paradoxically embraced as a language of native literature by state and society alike. Using Kamara’s body of work, colonial archival documents, and postcolonial knowledge production within Senegal, I make a case for a literary and intellectual-historical approach to the field of Islam in Africa. More importantly, I present Kamara’s story as a parable about the fate of the humanities after colonialism." This seminar is based on a pre-circulated paper to be read in advance. To receive a copy of the paper, please register.
tags: julien j. studley graduate programs in international affairs

title: Beyond the Written Word: On Touch and Breathing
description: Guest Lecture By Prof. Francesca Romana Recchia LucianiOpen to New School faculty and students only due to space limitations. Must have a @newschool.edu email address to register.The global viral epidemic COVID-19, which has progressively invested all continents since January 2020, has shown the bankrupt cruelty of the typically predatory neoliberal economic model, built on the plundering of natural resources and the destruction of the biosphere and the planet. A philosophical perspective for the contemporary world and for future generations must think of new paradigms of coexistence starting from the living body, a “singular plural” political entity that grounds the community, and from the con-tact between bodies as an expression of the sense of the “in-common”. Jean-Luc Nancy’s haptic ontology, reread through Irigaray and Derrida, identifies the experience of touching as the basis of inter-human relations and that of breathing as a shared right between humanity and the biosphere.
department: The New School For Social Research

title: Sennait Ghebreab on Responsible Fashion Business in Practice
description: Join us for an exclusive evening with Sennait Ghebreab, one of the authors of the highly acclaimed book Responsible Fashion Business in Practice. As Francesca Ragazzi, Head of Editorial Content at Vogue Italia, states, this book is "an essential guide for every responsible business leader and consumer." The groundbreaking Responsible 9 Framework introduced in the book provides invaluable insights with contemporary case studies that bring each of the 9 elements to life. Paolo Taticchi, Professor at UCL School of Management, calls it "a must-read for all fashion business leaders, students, and fashion consumers who want to make more informed purchase decisions," while  Eva Baquedano, CEO of LOEWE in Asia, praises its ability to re-think sustainability across all stages of the product lifecycle. Don't miss this opportunity to engage with Sennait Ghebreab as she shares her vision for a more sustainable fashion future, offering a powerful guide to both industry leaders and conscious consumers alike.  We look forward to seeing you at this special event!
tag_note: Assigned academic topic as Other since Fashion Business is not explicitly listed, however it relates to business and sustainability. Main category is Academic as the event features a speaker lecturing on the topic and Parsons School of Design is involved. Tags were assigned to capture the key themes of fashion design and sustainable business practices.

title: Visiting Artist: Joy Episalla
description: Joy Episalla is a New York-based interdisciplinary artist whose work repositions photography and the moving image into the territory of sculpture. Engaging a queer/feminist perspective they create open-ended situations that prompt the viewer to slow down and take in the moment, in all its complexity and seeming contradictions. Episalla has been exhibiting in the US and internationally since the 1990s. Museum exhibitions include Palais de Tokyo (Paris), MoMA PS1 (NYC), ICA (Philadelphia), Centre Pompidou (Paris), Victoria and Albert Museum (London), Leslie-Lohman Museum (NYC), Fondation Pernod Ricard (Paris), the Wexner (Columbus), Central for Contemporary Art (Brussels), Artist Space (NYC), Phoenix Art Museum (Phoenix), and the International Center for Photography (NYC). Writing about her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Artforum, BOMB, the New York Times, Two Coats of Paint, POST Italia, Slate, and Art in America. Their work is included in the collections of the Rose Art Museum, Centre Pompidou, Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, Baltimore Museum of Art, Buffalo AKG Gallery, and the Victoria & Albert Museum. Episalla is the recipient of a 2003 Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation Award. A longtime AIDS activist and member of the ACT UP affinity group the Marys, Episalla is included in the Smithsonian’s Archives of American Art Artist Oral History Project and is a board member of TAG Treatment Action Group. They are a founding member of the queer art collective fierce pussy with Nancy Brooks Brody (1962-2023), Zoe Leonard and Carrie Yamaoka, whose on-going work has been in the public sphere since 1991. Episalla is represented by Tibor de Nagy gallery (NYC), where she had a solo exhibition in 2022. Upcoming exhibitions include Chapter Eight of arms ache avid aeon: Nancy Brooks Brody / Joy Episalla / Zoe Leonard / Carrie Yamaoka: fierce pussy amplified, curated by Jo-ey Tang at Participant Inc. from March 2– May 11 2025 in NYC.

title: A Conversation with Chandelier Creative
description: Join the MPS Fashion Management program for an exclusive conversation with the leadership team from Chandelier Creative, a renowned creative agency founded in 2005 which collaborates with visionary brands to craft iconic identities and invent new worlds. Known for their world-class creative direction, human-centered strategy, multimedia design and production, and near-mythical storytelling, Chandelier has worked with prestigious clients such as Hermès, Equinox, KHAITE, Nike, Rhode, and Flamingo Estate.
tag_note: No tags or academic topics directly related to the creative fields were available.

title: Sociology Colloquium | Flexible Authoritarianism: Cultivating Ambition and Loyalty in Russia by Anna Schwenck
description: The Sociology Department at the New School for Social Research presents a talk by Dr. Anna Schwenck of the University of Siegen (Department of Social Sciences) on her award-winning book, Flexible Authoritarianism. Winner of the 2024 Mary Douglas Prize for Best Book in the Sociology of Culture, Dr. Schwenck’s book challenges the notion that authoritarianism's transnational rise constitutes a backlash against economic globalization. Describing a governmental approach that simultaneously incentivizes a can-do spirit and suppresses dissent, the book points out resonances between authoritarian and neoliberal ideologies in today's comeback of strongman rule. Drawing on field observations, in-depth interviews, and analyses of video clips, it conveys the look and feel of flexible authoritarianism in Russia through the eyes of up-and-coming youth. The author analyzes ways in which the insignia of cool start-up capitalism and familiar cultural forms such as the summer camp help stabilize the regime, while also showing how up-and-coming youth both embrace and contest loyalty to the government. Bio: Anna Schwenck’s research lies at the intersection of cultural and political sociology. She is particularly interested in how cultural understandings, be they transnational or locally specific, shape political behaviour.  She studied the resonances between authoritarianism and neoliberalism in Russia, pandemic and science skepticism in German-speaking countries, and processes of re-traditionalization in popular music cultures. Her recent work investigates the role of liberation songs and narratives in conventional and contentious politics in South Africa.  Anna is employed at the University of Siegen’s department of social sciences and the Siegen-based collaborative research centre “Transformations of the Popular” (SFB 1472). She is also a visiting researcher at the University of the Western Cape’s Anthropology Department in South Africa. She earned a PhD in Sociology and an MA in Social Sciences from Humboldt University Berlin, as well as a BA in Cultural Studies from Viadrina European University, Frankfurt (Oder). She was a visiting student/scholar at University College London's School of Slavonic and East European Studies, the Sociology Department at the University of California (Berkeley), and the Russian State University for the Humanities (Moscow).
department: The New School For Social Research

title: Mannes Fall Chamber Music Festival
description: Join us for the inaugural Fall Chamber Music FestivalPresented by the Mannes School of Music, the Chamber Music Festival is a special weeklong series of performances that highlights student accomplishments in chamber music over the course of a semester. This year, we have created a number of new specialized and diversified courses, broadened our chamber music performance opportunities, built new partnerships with our community both in and outside of The New School, and so much more. We are very excited to showcase our new offerings, so please join us in these special events.Register once for your ChamberPass and receive access to the entire festival. Ernst C. Stiefel HallThursday November 7, 2024 7:00pmFriday November 8, 2024 7:00pmSunday November 10, 2024 2:00pm and 7:00pmMonday November 11, 2024 7:00pmTuesday November 12, 2024 7:00pmWednesday November 13, 2024 7:00pmThursday November 14, 2024 7:00pm Programming:An Evening of French MusicThursday, 7 November from 7-9pm in Stiefel HallJoin us for our opening night of the Chamber Music Festival Concert Series, in which we will be hearing a diversity of instrumental groups exploring the rich, colorful music of late Romantic and early 20th-century French composers.Piano Extravaganza: A Night of Keyboard-Only EnsemblesFriday, 8 November from 7-9:30pm in Stiefel HallJoin us for night two of the Chamber Music Festival Concert Series: a fun-filled night of keyboard-only ensembles! Featuring music for 1-piano/4-hands, 1-piano/6-hands, and 2 pianos, and spanning from Schubert and Mozart through Ligeti and Bolcom, a night like this has not happened within the chamber music program at Mannes ever before.Early through Late Romanticism: From Bottesini through RachmaninoffSunday, 10 November from 2-4:30pm in Stiefel HallJoin us for the third concert of the Chamber Music Festival Concert Series, as we cross through the entire range of the Romantic period. Featuring duos, trios, quartets, and quintets by some of the great composers of the later half of the Common Practice Period, this afternoon concert will be memorable!Music of the 20th and 21st Century: Night 1Sunday, 10 November from 7-9pm in Stiefel HallJoin us for our first night of a special showcase on modern music! Featuring music from the early classics of Ravel through music composed by Ewazen in the 1990s, this night highlights how music has developed since the beginning of the “modern” era of composition.German and Austrian Music of the Pre-Romantic EraMonday, 11 November from 7-9pm in Stiefel HallJoin us for the fifth concert of the Chamber Music Festival Concert Series, in which we will be exploring the music of Bach, Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven! From brass ensembles through string quartets, this night will explore the range of music of our most cherished early composers.Europe in the 1800s: From Rossini through DebussyTuesday, 12 November from 7-9:30pm in Stiefel HallIn the sixth concert of the Chamber Music Festival Concert Series, we will hear some of the most famous music by Rossini, Schubert, Brahms, Mendelssohn, and even one of Debussy’s earliest works. From piano duets, to brass ensembles, to a sextet for piano and strings featuring our own viola faculty member John Pickford Richards, this night will explore all kinds of chamber ensembles!Music of the 20th- and 21st-Century: Night 2Wednesday, 13 November from 7-9pm in Stiefel HallJoin us for our second night of a special showcase on modern music, in which we will hear music written from well-known composers, music written and coached by our own esteemed faculty composition faculty member Joan La Barbara, and even music by our own students! This night will be a special treat, in which we will be utilizing prepared piano techniques, audio technology paired with acoustic instruments, and more!Grand FinaleThursday, 14 November from 7-10pm in Stiefel HallIn our grand finale of the inaugural Chamber Music Festival Concert Series, we will hear the most diverse night of music of the festival: featuring music for brass, winds, pianos, and strings, students in standard ensembles and in mixed ensembles, repertoire spanning from duos to septets, and even a special performance by our new Assistant Professor of Chamber Music, Daniel Panner, this night will be a jam-packed celebration of chamber music as a whole.Join us! Upcoming!Spring Chamber Music FestivalErnst C. title: Conflict Resolution with Soul Focused
description: The Provost's Office continues to source opportunities to build our community's capacity to engage in meaningful dialogue, support peaceful protest, and de-escalate situations in the classroom and on campus. Skill-building and human connection are critical to creating a community of care.  Soul Focused, a grassroots leadership development organization, will lead this comprehensive training for faculty and staff on de-escalation and conflict resolution. Role plays will address strategies for de-escalating and maintaining safe environments on campus. This workshop is designed for New School faculty and staff. If you are a student interested in attending a training, please reach out to provost@newschool.edu.

title: The Art of Change Opera 0.2 : A Prelude and a Reading
description: Jean-Baptiste Barriere's The ART of CHANGE OPERA was born from the desire to put philosophy into music and create a new art form based on a software that captures the sound of the voice and transforms it into a musical score. In the historical 12th street auditorium, where Martin Luther King gave his lectures on the American race crisis, and next to the room that Orozco filled with images of revolution, we will be asking ourselves: Where is the revolution gone? How is change possible in an epoch when everything has to be produced “Just-in-time”? What could the revolution of our time look like? The musical prelude will tell us the story of a society that has decided to apply the principle of accelerated change to all aspects of social life, while the speakers assembled in the reading will speculate about where we might possibly be heading. The musical prelude will feature:Jean-Baptiste Barrière, concept, musical composition & videoChiara Bottici, libretto and narrationCamilla Hoitenga, flutistMatteo Procuranti, libretto, actor and stage directorTimo Rissanen and Otto Von Busch, costumes. Speakers will include, among others: Austin Burke, Nancy Fraser, Lydia Goehr, Gwenda-lin Grewal, Lewis Gordon, Ashley Jones, Francesca Romana Recchia-Luciani, Veronica Dakota Padilla, Nelson Maldonado-Torres, Romy Opperman, Rose Rejouis, Nicol Shestani and McKenzie Wark.

title: Screening: THIS IS NOT A WAR STORY
description: Join this special Veteran's Day screening of THIS IS NOT A WAR STORY with director and assistant professor of Screen Studies, Talia Lugacy. Followed by Q&A with Paul Chaffin, New School alum and veteran, and Claude S. Copeland, Jr., veteran and member of About Face: Veterans Against War.Bios:Claude S. Copeland, Jr.Claude is a first generation American of Jamaican descent. He is a Black Army veteran, educator, organizer, and healing practitioner. While serving in the Army, he was deployed to Iraq for fifteen months from April 2003 to July 2004. He has been a member of About Face, formerly Iraq Veterans Against the War, for close to ten years and has served on the Board for two separate terms. Currently, he’s a high school teacher in the Bronx.Paul ChaffinPaul enlisted in the United States Marine Corps in 2006 at the age of 17, serving throughout East Asia with the 31st MEU (Camp Hansen, Okinawa), and later deploying to Afghanistan with CLR-2 (Camp Lejeune, NC). He is a New School alumnus and lives in Astoria.

title: CD Lecture Series: Ana Rice
description: Ana Rice graduated with a BFA in Graphic Design and a minor in Photography from Virginia State University and later earned a Master's degree in Branding from the School of Visual Arts. She began her career as a designer at a law firm in Richmond, Virginia before moving to New York, where she has been designing ever since. Her experience includes working with Cassandra (a strategy agency focused on young consumers), Afropunk (the music festival), and Droga5 (the advertising agency). In 2023, Ana transitioned to freelance design, collaborating with notable brands such as Apple, Warby Parker, and Converse. Beyond her full-time work, Ana is passionate about building brands for minority- and women-owned businesses, groups that are often overlooked.Event flyer design by @nick.massarelli

title: Telling the Bees: ﻿Dominic Pettman in Conversation with Elvia Wilk
description: Join Dominic Pettman, University Professor of Media and New Humanities, as he launches his new book, Telling the Bees: An Interspecies Monologue, in conversation with Elvia Wilk, NSSR Liberal Studies alum and author of Oval and Death by Landscape. In a bid to wean himself off social media, media scholar and cultural theorist Dominic Pettman decided to revive an ancient custom. He decided to tell the local bees of his thoughts, theories, musings, and meditations. The result was an apian journal that parses the daily news and the routines of modern life in a more sustained and reflective way than the Pavlovian posts to which we are so addicted.The account that emerges from Pettman’s regular discussion with the bees forms a compelling portrait of the tumultuous period running from the Fall of 2019 to New Year’s Eve 2022. What began as a reflection on the traumatic effects of an “unprecedented” presidency soon evolved into a real-time response to the equally extraordinary events of the pandemic and its aftermath.One key concern that emerges from Pettman’s ongoing discussion with the bees is the extent to which, thanks to the alienating effects of neoliberalism, we were already engaged in an advanced form of social distancing long before anyone had heard of COVID. Other key themes include education, human-animal relations, climate change, mediated intimacy, attention ecologies, collective memory, slow violence, the self-fulfilling prophecy that is New York City, the never-ending end of history, and the mundane strategies we share in a bid to forge on, despite the accumulating challenges of the twenty-first century.Telling the Bees is an invitation to rediscover the art of reflection and a profound meditation on human connection, alienation, and our collective yearning for intimacy in an age of distance.

title: ONLINE | Creative Courage: Navigating Sensitive Narratives in Ghana’s Media Landscape
description: Join us for an engaging Industry Talk featuring bold artists working at the intersection of creativity and activism in West Africa. Cutting-edge Ghanaian visionaries, Joewackle Kusi, Maame Adjei, and Percy Osei-Appiah (Mutombo) will share their experiences navigating the challenges of media-making in politically charged environments amid a rise in censorship. This panel will explore the ethical and practical dilemmas faced by filmmakers, producers, and artists while championing marginalized voices and identities such as Kusi’s bold examination of queer narratives in Nyame Mma; Maame Adjei’s award winning directorial debut in “The Whites of our Eyes”; and Mutombo's intimate storytelling.  This Industry Talk is essential for students to grasp the real-world consequences of censorship, creative suppression, and the ethical responsibilities of media creators. With diverse backgrounds in film, television, photography, and poetry, the panelists provide students with a multi-faceted understanding of how media can be used to represent marginalized voices and challenge oppressive systems, making this an invaluable earning opportunity for media managers and aspiring content creators alike.Don't miss this chance to engage with leading figures who are reshaping the landscape of media in Ghana and beyond!

title: General Seminar | Simon Critchley, "Mysticism"
description: Why mysticism? It has been called “experience in its most intense form,” and in his new book, Mysticism (New York Review of Books, October 2024), Simon Critchley, Hans Jonas Professor of Philosophy, poses a simple question to the reader: Wouldn’t you like to taste this intensity? Wouldn’t you like to be lifted up and out of yourself into a sheer feeling of aliveness, both your life and those of the creatures that surround you? If so, it might be well worthwhile trying to learn what is meant by mysticism and how it can shift, elevate, and deepen the sense of our lives. This event is part of The New School for Social Research's General Seminar event series. Refreshments will be served. Open to New School community members only. Must have an @newschool.edu email address to register.

title: ONLINE | PLM/PDM Programs: BeProduct Workshop
description: We invite the New School community for an engaging workshop focused on Product Lifecycle Management (PLM) systems—technologies that help businesses manage all aspects of a product's life cycle, from design to disposal! We’re excited to welcome Darioush Nikpour, a leading expert in PLM/PDM and the visionary behind BeProduct, a leading PLM solution. He will share his extensive experience in integrating 3D and digitalization into fashion design. The event will kick off with a brief overview of the business aspects by Bjorn Bengtsson, followed by a hands-on demo of the software, showcasing its application across organizations of various sizes. Don’t miss this opportunity to gain valuable insights into PLM systems and traceability software that enhance communication and visibility within the fashion supply chain.RSVP for a unique learning experience that will elevate your understanding of fashion supply chain technology.A Zoom link will be emailed after registering for the event.

title: Trajectories of Authoritarianism in Democratic Regimes
description: In an era of global democratic decline, elected leaders have tapped economic and other grievances and resentments, harnessed new coalitions, and created popular narratives that legitimize the concentration of power in single parties and individuals. The government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in India has compromised the integrity and independence of state institutions, and attacked civil society actors, media, academia, and opposition parties. But national elections earlier this year brought surprising results, with Modi’s party losing its parliamentary majority and now governing through a coalition. In Turkey, President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and his ruling party were also handed a surprising electoral defeat in local elections in March 2024. Elections in the United States on November 5 for control of the presidency and Congress are among the most closely contested in recent decades, and with the results likely to face legal challenges after Election Day. Through a comparative discussion of India, Turkey, and the United States, this panel will explore how to understand the authoritarian turn, varying modes of repressive governance within democracies and bases of its support, and the channels through which opposition parties and social movements have navigated the fraught political landscape.
